io.atomix.copycat.server

Class CopycatServer

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.atomix.copycat.server.CopycatServer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Managed<CopycatServer>

    public class CopycatServer
extends Object
implements Managed<CopycatServer>
    Provides a standalone implementation of the Raft consensus algorithm.

    To create a new server, use the server CopycatServer.Builder. Servers require cluster membership information in order to perform communication. Each server must be provided a local Address to which to bind the internal Server and a set of addresses for other members in the cluster.

    Underlying each server is a StateMachine. The state machine is responsible for maintaining the state with relation to Commands and Querys submitted to the server by a client. 

       
   Address address = new Address("123.456.789.0", 5000);
   Collection<Address> members = Arrays.asList(new Address("123.456.789.1", 5000), new Address("123.456.789.2", 5000));

   CopycatServer server = CopycatServer.builder(address, members)
     .withStateMachine(new MyStateMachine())
     .build();
    Server state machines are responsible for registering Commands which can be submitted to the cluster. Raft relies upon determinism to ensure consistency throughout the cluster, so it is imperative that each server in a cluster have the same state machine with the same commands.

    By default, the server will use the NettyTransport for communication. You can configure the transport via CopycatServer.Builder.withTransport(Transport).

    As Commands are received by the server, they're written to the Raft Log and replicated to other members of the cluster. By default, the log is stored on disk, but users can override the default Storage configuration via CopycatServer.Builder.withStorage(Storage). Most notably, to configure the storage module to store entries in memory instead of disk, configure the StorageLevel. 

     
 CopycatServer server = CopycatServer.builder(address, members)
   .withStateMachine(new MyStateMachine())
   .withStorage(new Storage(StorageLevel.MEMORY))
   .build();
    All serialization is performed with a Catalyst Serializer. By default, the serializer loads registered CatalystSerializable types with ServiceLoaderTypeResolver, but users can provide a custom serializer via CopycatServer.Builder.withSerializer(Serializer). The server will still ensure that internal serializable types are properly registered on user-provided serializers.

    Once the server has been created, to connect to a cluster simply open() the server. The server API is fully asynchronous and relies on CompletableFuture to provide promises: 

     
 server.open().thenRun(() -> {
   System.out.println("Server started successfully!");
 });
    When the server is started, it will attempt to connect to an existing cluster. If the server cannot find any existing members, it will attempt to form its own cluster.

    Once the server is started, it will communicate with the rest of the nodes in the cluster, periodically transitioning between states. Users can listen for state transitions via onStateChange(Consumer): 

     
 server.onStateChange(state -> {
   if (state == CopycatServer.State.LEADER) {
     System.out.println("Server elected leader!");
   }
 });
    Author:
    Jordan Halterman
    See Also:
    StateMachine, Transport, Storage

    • Method Detail

      • builder

        public static CopycatServer.Builder builder(Address address,
                                            Address... cluster)
        Returns a new Raft server builder.

        The provided Address is the address to which to bind the server being constructed. The provided set of members will be used to connect to the other members in the Raft cluster. The local server Address does not have to be present in the address list.

        The returned server builder will use the NettyTransport by default. Additionally, serializable types will be registered using the ServiceLoaderTypeResolver. To register serializable types for the server, simply add a Serializer or CatalystSerializable file to your META-INF/services folder on the classpath.

        Parameters:
        address - The address through which clients and servers connect to this server.
        cluster - The cluster members to which to connect.
        Returns:
        The server builder.

      • state

        public CopycatServer.State state()
        Returns the Copycat server state.

        The initial state of a Raft server is CopycatServer.State.INACTIVE. Once the server is started and until it is explicitly shutdown, the server will be in one of the active states - CopycatServer.State.PASSIVE, CopycatServer.State.FOLLOWER, CopycatServer.State.CANDIDATE, or CopycatServer.State.LEADER.

        Returns:
        The Copycat server state.

      • onStateChange

        public Listener<CopycatServer.State> onStateChange(Consumer<CopycatServer.State> listener)
        Registers a state change listener.

        Throughout the lifetime of the cluster, the server will periodically transition between various states. Users can listen for and react to state change events. To determine when this server is elected leader, simply listen for the CopycatServer.State.LEADER state. 

           
   server.onStateChange(state -> {
     if (state == CopycatServer.State.LEADER) {
       System.out.println("Server elected leader!");
     }
   });
        Parameters:
        listener - The state change listener.
        Returns:
        The listener context. This can be used to unregister the election listener via Listener.close().
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If listener is null

      • context

        public ThreadContext context()
        Returns the server execution context.

        The thread context is the event loop that this server uses to communicate other Raft servers. Implementations must guarantee that all asynchronous CompletableFuture callbacks are executed on a single thread via the returned ThreadContext.

        The ThreadContext can also be used to access the Raft server's internal serializer via ThreadContext.serializer(). Catalyst serializers are not thread safe, so to use the context serializer, users should clone it: 

           
   Serializer serializer = server.threadContext().serializer().clone();
   Buffer buffer = serializer.writeObject(myObject).flip();
        Returns:
        The server thread context.

      • open

        public CompletableFuture<CopycatServer> open()
        Starts the Raft server asynchronously.

        When the server is started, the server will attempt to search for an existing cluster by contacting all of the members in the provided members list. If no existing cluster is found, the server will immediately transition to the CopycatServer.State.FOLLOWER state and continue normal Raft protocol operations. If a cluster is found, the server will attempt to join the cluster. Once the server has joined or started a cluster and a leader has been found, the returned CompletableFuture will be completed.

        Specified by:
        open in interface Managed<CopycatServer>
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the server has joined the cluster and a leader has been found.

      • isOpen

        public boolean isOpen()
        Specified by:
        isOpen in interface Managed<CopycatServer>

      • close

        public CompletableFuture<Void> close()
        Specified by:

      • isClosed

        public boolean isClosed()
        Returns a boolean value indicating whether the server is running.

        Once open() is called and the returned CompletableFuture is completed (meaning this server found a cluster leader), this method will return true until closed.

        Specified by:
        isClosed in interface Managed<CopycatServer>
        Returns:
        Indicates whether the server is running.

      • kill
